blogCattleNutrition.heroTitle: Feeding strategies for dairy animals in India — better health and higher milk yield
blogCattleNutrition.heroDesc: In dairy, feeding is usually the biggest expense (often ~60–70% of milk production cost). The goal is simple: meet maintenance + milk production + pregnancy needs and keep the rumen healthy.
blogCattleNutrition.heroNote: Note: This page is organized in Verdant style and is an educational guide based on your pasted “Feeding Strategies…” content (Pashudhan Praharee / Technical Team, Livestock Institute of Training & Development / “Dugdhvahini”).
blogCattleNutrition.whyDesc: Milk yield, fat %, reproduction, and disease resistance — especially in early lactation and late pregnancy — are directly linked to energy and protein balance.
blogCattleNutrition.realities1: Feed is the largest recurring cost; wastage or imbalance reduces profit immediately.
blogCattleNutrition.realities2: Roughage quality changes with seasons; plan legume + non-legume fodder across the year.
blogCattleNutrition.realities3: Negative energy balance is common in early lactation in high-yielding cows — increasing metabolic issues and heat delay risk.
blogCattleNutrition.realities4: The rumen is the “engine”: imbalance in concentrate/roughage can cause acidosis and milk fat drop.
blogCattleNutrition.nonNeg1: Clean water 24×7 (water increases dry matter intake).
blogCattleNutrition.nonNeg2: Fixed feeding time; avoid sudden diet changes.
blogCattleNutrition.nonNeg3: Adequate fiber (often a target of ~20–25% crude fiber in milking animals).
blogCattleNutrition.nonNeg4: Mineral mix + common salt as recommended.
blogCattleNutrition.energyTitle: Energy: manage negative energy balance in early lactation
blogCattleNutrition.energyDesc: Milk peaks at ~4–8 weeks after calving, while dry matter intake often lags until ~10–14 weeks — creating a gap. The cow uses body reserves, increasing metabolic disorder and infertility risk.
blogCattleNutrition.energyLowTitle: What goes wrong when energy is low
blogCattleNutrition.energyLow1: Lower milk yield and weaker persistence.
blogCattleNutrition.energyLow3: Body condition loss → lower disease resistance.
blogCattleNutrition.energyLow4: Higher chance of metabolic problems if diet isn’t adjusted.
blogCattleNutrition.energyStrategy1: Intake is limited in early lactation → energy density must increase.
blogCattleNutrition.energyStrategy2: Grain can help, but too much grain increases acidosis and milk fat depression risk.
blogCattleNutrition.energyStrategy3: Safer option: fat supplementation — increase energy without overfeeding grain (prefer rumen-stable/bypass fats).
blogCattleNutrition.energyStrategy4: Avoid feeding large amounts of unsaturated vegetable oils directly (can affect fiber-digesting rumen bacteria).
blogCattleNutrition.fatSupp1: Bypass fats are digested later with less rumen disturbance.
blogCattleNutrition.fatSupp2: Rumen-protected forms (e.g., calcium salts/soaps) can have palatability issues and may be unstable at low pH.
blogCattleNutrition.fatSupp3: Rumen-stable fats (saturated fatty acids rich in palmitic acid) stay stable in rumen pH and support energy.
blogCattleNutrition.fatSupp4: Field practice: increase fats gradually and monitor dung, milk fat %, appetite/intake.
blogCattleNutrition.proteinDesc: Ruminants get amino acids mainly from microbial protein (made in the rumen) + RUP/bypass protein (digested in the intestine). High yielders often need more bypass protein.
blogCattleNutrition.microbial1: Rumen microbes can convert NPN (urea/ammonia) into microbial protein — if fermentable energy is sufficient.
blogCattleNutrition.microbial2: If ammonia release is high and energy is low (too much RDP/low energy), efficiency drops and less microbial protein is made.
blogCattleNutrition.microbial3: Growing/finishing cattle use NPN better than high-producing lactating cows.
blogCattleNutrition.bypassTitle: Bypass protein (RUP) — to improve milk protein
blogCattleNutrition.bypass1: In high-producing cows, microbes alone may not meet amino acid demand.
blogCattleNutrition.bypass2: Add proteins that break down less in the rumen and reach the intestine (RUP).
blogCattleNutrition.bypass3: A common target ratio in some programs: ~65:35 (RDP:RUP) — adjust as per forage quality and production.
blogCattleNutrition.bypass4: If the basal diet is high in RDP, focus on RUP instead of increasing RDP — milk protein yield can improve.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumTitle: Chromium: support energy use in transition
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumDesc: Transition (~21 days prepartum to ~21 days postpartum) is the most critical period. Chromium is linked to insulin sensitivity and glucose use; organic forms may absorb better than inorganic forms.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumWhyTitle: Why it’s discussed in high yielders
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumWhy1: May support glucose utilization via insulin sensitivity (glucose tolerance factor concept).
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumWhy2: Reported benefits in some programs: intake support in early lactation and better immune response.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumWhy3: Use only with guidance — first strengthen balanced ration, minerals, and transition management.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumCaution1: Inorganic chromium absorbs less; chelated/organic (e.g., nicotinate/picolinate) are considered more available.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumCaution2: Don’t treat it as a “magic powder” — negative energy balance is mainly solved by diet energy density + intake + comfort.
blogCattleNutrition.chromiumCaution3: Check label dose and consult a vet/nutritionist for supplements.
blogCattleNutrition.thumbRulesTitle: Thumb rules farmers actually use (from your source)
blogCattleNutrition.thumbRulesDesc: These rules are popular because they’re simple. Adapt them based on breed, body weight, fodder quality, and milk fat %.
blogCattleNutrition.compound1: Growing animals: often ~1–2 kg compound cattle feed/day.
blogCattleNutrition.compound2: Milking: ~2 kg maintenance + extra per liter of milk (e.g., thumb rule: cow ~400 g/liter, buffalo ~500 g/liter).
blogCattleNutrition.compound3: Pregnant: in the last 2 months, extra concentrate/oil cake is recommended for fetal growth and good condition.
blogCattleNutrition.stageDryCowRule2: • Pregnant: add ~1.5 kg concentrate from the 7th month
blogCattleNutrition.stageDryCowRule3: • Poor condition: up to ~1 kg concentrate may be used
blogCattleNutrition.stageMilchCowRule1: • Cow: ~1 kg concentrate per ~2.5 kg milk (approx. 4% fat)
blogCattleNutrition.stageMilchCowRule2: • Buffalo: ~1 kg concentrate per ~2.0 kg milk
blogCattleNutrition.challengeTitle: Challenge feeding SOP (pre-calving to peak yield)
blogCattleNutrition.challengeDesc: Goal: prepare the rumen/digestive system for higher concentrate and safely support peak yield.
blogCattleNutrition.sop1: Start ~2 weeks before the expected calving date.
blogCattleNutrition.sop3: Increase by ~300–400 g daily until intake reaches ~500–1000 g per 100 kg body weight.
blogCattleNutrition.sop4: After calving: increase by ~500 g/day in the first 2 weeks up to free-choice level; then set as per test-day milk.
blogCattleNutrition.allowance1: Start ~500 g; increase ~300–400 g/day until ~500–1000 g per 100 kg BW
blogCattleNutrition.allowance2: Increase ~500 g/day and move to free-choice level
blogCattleNutrition.allowance3: Free-choice (monitor rumen health, dung, milk fat)
blogCattleNutrition.allowance4: Fix as per production thumb rule (e.g., ~1 kg per 2.5 kg milk)
blogCattleNutrition.midLateTitle: Mid and late lactation: stability, then rebuild condition
blogCattleNutrition.midLateDesc: Mid lactation is more stable; in late lactation intake may improve and body reserves rebuild — along with pregnancy needs.
blogCattleNutrition.midLate1: Mid lactation: feed a balanced ration; keep quality fodder and adjust concentrate based on milk/fat%.
blogCattleNutrition.midLate2: Late lactation: appetite often improves; allow body reserve recovery while meeting fetal needs.
blogCattleNutrition.midLate3: In ~7.5 to 10 months of lactation, some systems add ~1–2 kg concentrate beyond maintenance + production to improve body condition (as per breed/timeline).
blogCattleNutrition.highProdDesc: High producers can’t sustain production on bulky forage alone, but too much concentrate can cause acidosis and milk fat depression. Control fermentation through composition, ratio, amount, frequency, and form.
blogCattleNutrition.controls1: Use better quality forage to reduce concentrate requirement.
blogCattleNutrition.controls2: In milking animals, minimum crude fiber ~20–25% is often cited (supports acetate and milk fat).
blogCattleNutrition.controls3: Split feeding into 3–4 parts to reduce acid spikes and improve utilization.
blogCattleNutrition.controls4: Watch signals: loose dung, less cud chewing, sudden milk fat drop → rebalance the ration.
blogCattleNutrition.tmr1: A complete diet mixes roughage + concentrate — reduces selective eating.
blogCattleNutrition.tmr2: Benefits: intake may improve, rumen stays stable, labor reduces, and concentrate overeating/acidosis risk decreases.
blogCattleNutrition.tmr3: Group feeding is common; formula needs changing less often.
blogCattleNutrition.allowancesDesc: Use as a starting point; then adjust based on fodder quality, milk fat %, season, and body condition.
blogCattleNutrition.mineralsTitle: Minerals and vitamins (what to include and why)
blogCattleNutrition.mineralsDesc: Minerals and vitamins affect milk production, fertility, immunity, and bone health. Deficiency signs: low yield, weak bones, weak heat signs, frequent illness.
blogCattleNutrition.majorMinerals1: Calcium: bones/teeth, nerve-muscle function, clotting. Deficiency: rickets (young), osteomalacia (adult), milk fever after calving.
blogCattleNutrition.majorMinerals2: Phosphorus: energy metabolism (ATP), bones, fertility. Deficiency: pica, weak joints, weak fertility/estrus.
blogCattleNutrition.majorMinerals3: Magnesium: enzyme activator; deficiency can cause grass tetany (tremors/staggering).
blogCattleNutrition.majorMinerals4: Sodium/chloride/potassium: fluid balance, nerve conduction; deficiency can reduce growth and cause weakness.
blogCattleNutrition.microMineralsTitle: Micro minerals and vitamins (short practical list)
blogCattleNutrition.microMinerals1: Iron: deficiency may be more common in fast-growing calves, especially on milk-only diets.
blogCattleNutrition.microMinerals2: Copper/zinc/manganese/cobalt/selenium/iodine: linked to immunity, skin, fertility, growth, thyroid.
blogCattleNutrition.microMinerals3: Vitamin A: vision, epithelial integrity, fertility; deficiency: night blindness, infection, reproductive issues.
blogCattleNutrition.microMinerals4: Vitamin D: calcium/phosphorus use; deficiency: rickets/osteomalacia.
blogCattleNutrition.microMinerals5: Vitamin E + selenium: antioxidants; deficiency can show white-muscle-disease-like signs.
blogCattleNutrition.actionPlanTitle: Action plan: what to do today / this week / this month
blogCattleNutrition.actionPlanDesc: Simple routines make the biggest difference. Use it like a farm checklist.
blogCattleNutrition.today1: Ensure clean water and check troughs.
blogCattleNutrition.today5: Record milk yield (morning/evening) and changes in appetite/intake.
blogCattleNutrition.week1: Check body condition score (thin/ideal/fat) for each milker.
blogCattleNutrition.week2: Adjust concentrate as per yield (thumb rule) and fat%.
blogCattleNutrition.week4: Plan green + dry fodder stock for the next 7–14 days.
blogCattleNutrition.month1: If milk fat is dropping or fertility issues are rising, review the ration with a local vet/extension worker.
blogCattleNutrition.month2: Review transition cow management (last 3 weeks before/after calving).
blogCattleNutrition.month3: Check mineral/vitamin supply chain and avoid expired stock.
blogCattleNutrition.month4: If using bypass fat/protein: review milk response + health indicators.
blogCattleNutrition.sourceText: “Feeding Strategies of Dairy Cattle in India for Good Health & Better Milk Yield” — This is a Verdant-formatted educational guide and not a substitute for veterinary advice.

blogLivestockDiseases.title: Common livestock diseases every Indian dairy farmer should watch for
blogLivestockDiseases.subtitle: A field-focused guide: what to observe, what to do first, what to record, and when to call a veterinarian. Fast action protects milk, fertility, and lives.

section60sCheck.item1: Appetite + water: a sudden drop is a major sign.
section60sCheck.item2: Dung: very watery / very dry / blood / foul smell → note immediately.
section60sCheck.item3: Cud chewing: reduced rumination often indicates rumen issue, pain, fever, or acidosis.
section60sCheck.item4: If the animal looks dull, measure temperature (normal range can vary; fever is a big sign).
section60sCheck.item5: Milk: clots, watery milk, blood, foul smell → suspect mastitis.
section60sCheck.item6: Feet/legs: lameness, swelling, hoof smell → lameness/foot rot.
section60sCheck.item7: Breathing: cough, nasal discharge, rapid/difficult breathing → respiratory infection.

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionEmergencyTitle: Emergency signs — call the vet immediately

sectionEmergency.item1: Animal has collapsed and can’t stand; severe weakness or tremors.
sectionEmergency.item2: Severe bloat (left side swelling), breathing difficulty.
sectionEmergency.item3: High fever + mouth sores / heavy drooling (suspect infectious disease).
sectionEmergency.item4: Blood in milk + swollen and painful udder.
sectionEmergency.item5: Sudden deaths or many animals sick at the same time.

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionCommonGroupsTitle: Most common problem groups on Indian dairy farms

udderMilk.firstActions: Separate the milker; keep milking routine clean; do a strip test; call the vet for a treatment plan

digestiveRumen.earlyClues: Less eating, less rumination, loose dung, belly swelling
digestiveRumen.firstActions: Stop sudden concentrate; give roughage; check water; if bloat/fever, call the vet

feetLegs.earlyClues: Limping, swelling, foul smell, less movement
feetLegs.firstActions: Keep floor clean and dry; clean hooves; for trimming/antibiotics, consult the vet as needed

reproduction.earlyClues: No heat signs, discharge, low conception
reproduction.firstActions: Nutrition + minerals; heat detection; vet check; transition period management

skinVector.firstActions: Tick control; shed cleaning; vet diagnosis

prevention.item1: Pre-dip (if used), clean and dry teats; use a separate cloth/tissue for each animal.
prevention.item2: Full-hand milking / correct machine settings (if using a machine). Avoid teat injury.
prevention.item4: Keep bedding dry and clean; remove dung frequently.
prevention.item5: Identify chronic cases and milk them last.

suspected.item1: Look for clots/watery milk; compare different quarters.
suspected.item2: Mark the animal; milk separately; do not mix milk in the bulk can.
suspected.item3: Record: date, affected quarter, fever yes/no, milk changes.
suspected.item4: Call the vet for correct therapy and milk withdrawal guidance.

bloat.title: Ways to reduce bloat risk
bloat.item1: Avoid sudden heavy grazing on very green/legume-rich fodder without adaptation.
bloat.item2: Give dry roughage before grazing green fodder.
bloat.item4: Monitor animals after diet changes; bloat can escalate quickly.

acidosis.title: Ways to reduce acidosis risk
acidosis.item1: Maintain enough fiber (roughage) for rumination and saliva buffering.
acidosis.item2: Feed concentrate in multiple portions instead of one heavy meal.
acidosis.item3: If milk fat drops suddenly + loose dung: suspect rumen imbalance.
acidosis.item4: For high producers, get the ration reviewed by a nutritionist.

biosecurity.item1: Quarantine new animals (separate pen) before mixing.
biosecurity.item2: Isolate sick animals; keep separate buckets/ropes for them.
biosecurity.item3: Footbath at entry (where possible) and regular shed disinfection.
biosecurity.item4: Control visitors, vehicles, and shared equipment between farms.
biosecurity.item5: Follow the local vaccination schedule (ask your vet/department).

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionTodayWeekMonthTitle: What to do today / this week / this month

today.item2: Check udder and milk during milking.

week.item1: Clean bedding + drainage; fix wet areas.

month.item1: Record conception/heat issues and consult the vet if repeat cases occur.
month.item3: Evaluate repeat mastitis cases and the milking hygiene SOP.

blogLivestockDiseases.noteText: This guide is educational. For correct diagnosis and medicines, decide only with a veterinarian — especially for infectious diseases and milk withdrawal rules.

blogSustainableFeeding.title: Sustainable feeding practices for modern Indian dairy farms
blogSustainableFeeding.subtitle: Sustainability is not “expensive tech.” It’s mostly: better fodder planning, less wastage, better rumen efficiency, clean water, and consistent SOPs.
blogSustainableFeeding.sectionCoreIdeaTitle: Core idea: improve conversion of every kg of feed into milk (not waste)

coreIdea.b1: Plan fodder supply by season (mix of legume + non-legume).
coreIdea.b2: Protect from mold, dust, and spoilage — these reduce intake and increase disease risk.
coreIdea.b3: Maintain roughage:concentrate balance to protect the rumen and keep milk fat.
coreIdea.b4: Keep water always clean and available.

yearRound.b1: Create a cropping calendar for green fodder availability.
yearRound.b2: Keep dry fodder reserves for lean months.
yearRound.b3: Store fodder above the ground; protect from moisture.

silage.b1: Silage stabilizes fodder availability and reduces spoilage loss.
silage.b2: Correct compaction and sealing are most important (air causes mold).
silage.b3: Start gradually; monitor intake and dung consistency.

precision.b1: Measure concentrate using a fixed mug/can (standardize per animal).
precision.b2: Adjust based on milk yield and body condition score (thin/ideal/fat).
precision.b3: For high producers, split concentrate into multiple portions (3–4 times/day).
precision.b4: Avoid sudden changes; if possible, adapt over 7–10 days.

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionWastageChecklistTitle: Wastage control checklist (the biggest hidden money leak)

r1.c3: Raised trough, correct height, smaller portions more frequently

r2.c3: Dry, ventilated, away from moisture; FIFO rotation

r3.c3: Uniform chop size; avoid dust; lightly moisten if needed

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionRumenFriendlyTitle: Rumen-friendly sustainability (more milk solids, fewer problems)

protect.b1: Enough fiber for rumination and saliva buffering.
protect.b2: Keep feeding times consistent (rumen microbes like routine).
protect.b3: Avoid over-grain that can cause acidosis and low milk fat.

rumen.waterTitle: Water is part of feeding too

water.b1: Less water → less dry matter intake → less milk.
water.b2: Keep water points near resting and feeding areas.
water.b3: In heat stress months, water availability becomes even more important.

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionWhatToDoTitle: What to do today / this week / this month

week.b1: Plan fodder needs for the next 2 weeks.
week.b3: Inspect storage for moisture and insects.

month.b1: Review milk yield trend and feed cost per liter.
month.b2: Adjust minerals and ration balance with a vet/extension worker.

blogSustainableFeeding.verdantNote: Sustainability is a system: fodder planning + storage + routine + rumen health + water + minerals. Small improvements add up to big profit.
